Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bacterial Flagellar Forests: Designing a Biomaterial for Bio-Enabled Sensing and Actuation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research funds the collaborative efforts of researchers at Drexel University and University of Nevada Reno to study bacterial flagella as a component of an active biomaterial that are capable of sensing and actuation. This collaborative project is cofunded by the Nano-Biosensing program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems. Bacterial flagella are helical self-assembled structures composed of flagellin subunits. Polymorphic transformations, a key property of flagella, depend on external stimuli including temperature, ionic strength, pH, optical forcing, and possibly by concentration of specific ligands. But the specific levels of stimuli needed to induce transformations have not been well-determined. The goal of the proposed work is to create a flagellar forest consisting of an array of flagella tethered to a substrate. In response to external stimuli, flagellar polymorphic transformations coupled to collective flagellar dynamics will enable the flagellar forest to sense and actuate autonomously in response to the environment. To accomplish the goal, the researchers will: (1) create flagellar forests by gathering filaments into ordered arrays tethered to magnetic motors on a substrate which are actuated by an external rotating magnetic field en masse; (2) characterize the response of individual flagella to thermal, chemical, mechanical, and optical environmental stimuli; and (3) understand how individual flagella interact to create the collective response of the flagellar forest biomaterial. The broader scientific impact of this collaborative project is in developing an understanding how macroscale autonomic behavior in biological systems that is controlled by charge and mass transport at the nanoscale, which, in turn, is controlled by the dynamic response of a vast array of polymeric biomolecules. The educational goal of this project is to effectively communicate cutting-edge research to younger and broader audiences and inspire them toward the goal of obtaining a degree in STEM fields.

The use of biological nanomaterials in an engineered system presents a critical step toward understanding how the biological world has evolved at the nanoscale, as well as how scientists and engineers can improve upon nature using modern assembly and synthesis techniques. The design of "smart" systems can take advantage of materials which can respond autonomously to changes in their surroundings. In addition, the work includes an extensive training component for graduate and undergraduate students, preparing them for careers in academia and industry with a comprehensive background in biology and engineering. Throughout the project, the PIs will continue to recruit and mentor underrepresented groups to work in STEM fields. The research will be communicated to the public through strong outreach efforts. At Drexel University, the INSPIRE academy will bring cutting-edge bionanomaterials and biomanufacturing to high school teachers and students. At the University of Nevada, Reno, the "Move Like a Microbe" program will bring this research to life for K-12 students and the public through University's "Engineer's Day", "Summer Engineering Camp", and "Mobile Engineering Education Lab" outreach programs. Additionally, web-based and social media outlets such as YouTube will be utilized to disseminate the scientific discoveries, and to make science more appealing to K-12 students, teachers and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we analyzed the physics underlying a proposed “Flagellar Forest,” a device constructed of many bacterial flagellar filaments each bonded to a magnetic bead and then attached to a surface. Flagella are helical filaments about 12-20 nm in diameter which are naturally produced by bacteria. They have the remarkable property of being able to change shape in response to environmental changes such as changes in temperature, pH, or ionic strength. These shape changes can change the length of flagella by up to a factor of three or change the handedness of the helical geometry from left- to right-handed.

 

The motivating concept behind the Flagellar Forest is that the surface-attached flagella can be rotated by an external rotating magnetic field. Like corkscrews or propellers turning in fluid, a rotating flagellum would induce a fluid flow. If all the flagella point in the same direction, this could lead to a net pumping effect. Crucially, the pumping has the potential to autonomously respond to changes in the environment which change the shape of flagella. For instance, we hypothesized that an environmental change which reversed the helicity of the flagella could reverse the direction of pumping. Therefore, for example, a Flagellar Forest could automatically reverse pumping direction if the pH changed, thus producing a flow which could counteract the pH change, and therefore acting as an element in a microfluidic device which maintains pH automatically.

 

The key intellectual merit of the project was that it was unknown how individual rotating flagella generate flows, and how a flagellar forest of many flagella collectively organize to tilt together and generate macroscopic flows. We created mathematical models of such rotating flagella near a surface to understand these phenomena.

 

Our first main result was that the pumping flow of individual flagella depends on their helical geometry and tilt angle. Opposite handedness flagella generate flows in opposite directions, and a tilt angle of about 45 degrees generates maximum flow along the surface. We examined the flow caused by all 11 shapes taken by bacterial flagella.

 

The second main result dealt with what happens when many flagella are rotated together. We found that if the handedness of the flagellum was such that rotation generated a flow away from the surface, that flow could induce nearby flagella to also tilt in the same direction as each other. For some geometries and rotation rates, this causes the flagellar forest to collectively organize to all tilt at the same angle, and then produce a pumping flow. If the flagella do not collectively tilt (due to the wrong rotation rates, or due to having the wrong handedness), then they do not produce pumping. This result tells us that if an external stimuli changes the handedness of flagella, the likely response of a flagellar forest is not to reverse the pumping flow, but instead to turn off the pumping flow. We found the magnetic field strengths, rotation rates, and flagella separations in the forest necessary to produce self-organized pumping.

 

The outcomes of the project included three journal publications, one journal publication in preparation, multiple conference and poster presentations, and multiple seminars and talks.

 

The broader impact of the work is that it moves us closer to developing microfluidic devices capable of autonomous response and control. Such devices could be useful in biomedical contexts, especially to maintain homeostasis of microfluidic environments. Furthermore, education and outreach activities were used to demonstrate the principles of microscale flows and propulsion to students in middle and high school. Two undergraduates received research experience, and two graduate students and one postdoctoral research associate were trained for the STEM workforce during this award.
